node.title: What ‘Structural Racism’ Really Means
node.description: As the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. wrote, “an edifice which produces beggars needs restructuring.”
node.content: ["Whether for inspiration, new ideas or simply as a refresher, it is important to revisit the classics of whatever constitutes your field of interest. It was with that in mind that I spent much of the weekend rereading the 1948 book, \u201cCaste, Class, and Race: A Study in Social Dynamics,\u201d an influential (if now somewhat obscure) work of sociological analysis by the Trinidadian scholar Oliver Cromwell Cox.", "If there is a reason to revisit this specific book at this particular moment, it is to remind oneself that the challenge of racism is primarily structural and material, not cultural and linguistic, and that a disproportionate focus on the latter can too often obscure the former.", "Cox was writing at a time when mainstream analysis of race in the United States made liberal use of an analogy to the Indian caste system in order to illustrate the vast gulf of experience that lay between Black and white Americans. His book was a rebuttal to this idea as well as an original argument in its own right.", "Over the course of 600 pages, Cox provides a systematic study of caste, class and race relations, underscoring the paramount differences between caste and race and, most important, tying race to the class system. \u201cRacial antagonism,\u201d he writes in the prologue, \u201cis part and parcel of this class struggle, because it developed within the capitalist system as one of its fundamental traits.\u201d", "Put differently, to the extent that Cox had a single problem with the \u201ccaste\u201d analysis of American racism, it was that it abstracted racial conflict away from its origins in the development of American capitalism. The effect was to treat racism as a timeless force, outside the logic of history.", "\u201cWe may reiterate that the caste school of race relations is laboring under the illusion of a simple but vicious truism,\u201d Cox wrote in a section criticizing the Swedish economist Gunnar Myrdal\u2019s famous study, \u201cAn American Dilemma: The Negro Problem and Modern Democracy.\u201d \u201cOne man is white, another is black; the cultural opportunities of these two men may be the same, but since the black man cannot become white, there will always be a white caste and a black caste.\u201d", "In Cox\u2019s reading of Myrdal, caste exists as an independent force, directing the energies and activities of Black and white people alike. The solution to the \u201crace problem,\u201d in this vision, is to shake whites of their psychological commitment to the caste system. Or, as Cox summarizes the point, \u201cIf the \u2018race problem\u2019 in the United States is pre-eminently a moral question, it must naturally be resolved by moral means.\u201d", "But this, for Cox, is nonsense. \u201cWe cannot defeat race prejudice by proving that it is wrong,\u201d he writes. \u201cThe reason for this is that race prejudice is only a symptom of a materialistic social fact.\u201d Specifically, \u201cRace prejudice is supported by a peculiar socioeconomic need which guarantees force in its protection; and, as a consequence, it is likely that at its centers of initiation force alone will defeat it.\u201d", "For most of American history, until the Civil War, this socioeconomic need was the production of tobacco, agricultural staples and, eventually, cotton. After the war, it was the general demand for cheap workers and a pliant, divided labor force coming from Southern planters and Northern industrialists. Whether in the United States or around the world, Cox argues, it is capitalist exploitation \u2014 and not some inborn tribalism \u2014 that drives racial prejudice and conflict.", "\u201cRace prejudice,\u201d Cox writes, \u201cdeveloped gradually in Western society as capitalism and nationalism developed. It is a divisive attitude seeking to alienate dominant group sympathy from an \u2018inferior\u2019 race, a whole people, for the purpose of facilitating its exploitation.\u201d What\u2019s more, \u201cThe greater the immediacy of the exploitative need, the more insistent were the arguments supporting the rationalizations.\u201d", "Although Cox was writing in a very different era than our own \u2014 Jim Crow ruled the American South and the dismantling of colonial empires was only just beginning \u2014 his insights still matter. We must remember that the problem of racism \u2014 of the denial of personhood and of the differential exposure to exploitation and death \u2014 will not be resolved by saying the right words or thinking the right thoughts.", "That\u2019s because racism does not survive, in the main, because of personal belief and prejudice. It survives because it is inscribed and reinscribed by the relationships and dynamics that structure our society, from segregation and exclusion to inequality and the degradation of labor.", "The solution, as the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. wrote the year of his assassination, must involve a \u201crevolution of values\u201d that will \u201clook uneasily on the glaring contrast of poverty and wealth\u201d and see that \u201can edifice which produces beggars needs restructuring.\u201d", "\u201cIf democracy is to have breadth of meaning,\u201d King declared, \u201cit is necessary to adjust this inequity. It is not only moral, but it is also intelligent. We are wasting and degrading human life by clinging to archaic thinking.\u201d"]
